questions.stem: A 32-year-old heavy smoker has cervical smear showing ASCUS. HPV test is positive. What is the best course of action in this situation?
options: Repeat smear and HPV test as soon as possible.

questions.stem: A 28-year-old woman with history of repeated vaginal infections and multiple sexual partners, had her smear result showing HSIL. Your next advice is:
options: Do HPV test to support diagnosis.
Repeat smear as soon as possible.

questions.stem: The most common malignancy in the female reproductive organs:
Ovarian neoplasm most commonly arise from:
Ovarian cancer is more likely to occur in all the following EXCEPT:
options: Patient with history of prolonged use of oral contraceptive pills.
Women with a family history of ovarian cancer.

questions.stem: US features of ovarian malignancy include all the following EXCEPT:
options: Capsule integrity is disrupted with projection.

questions.stem: Which of the following tumors produces estrogen:
Which of the following gynecological cancers is a leading cause of death:
Staging of ovarian carcinoma is based on:
options: CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis.
Surgical evaluation of the extent of intraabdominal disease.

questions.stem: Screening is most effective in preventing which of the following cancers:
Untreated patients with cancer of the cervix usually die with:
Risk factors of cervical cancer include all the following EXCEPT:
The most common clinical presentation of early cervical cancer is:

A 26-year-old NG, presents to ER with severe Rt lower quadrant pain that started last night. Pain is worse this morning associated with nausea & vomiting. She had a normal menstrual flow that ended 2 days ago. Her vital signs are normal, examination reveals a markedly tender right lower quadrant mass with rebound tenderness. TVS showed a 6 cm right cystic adnexal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
What could be a predisposing factor for this condition?
What is the possible sequelae of the condition?
What further investigations would confirm your diagnosis?
What is the most suitable management?

A 32-year-old obese G3P0 comes for a routine gynecologic examination. She started sexual activity at the age of 15 years, and gives history of multiple sexual partners. She has 3 first trimesteric abortions, used Depo-provera for birth control. She has a history of genital warts. She does not use drugs but admits to smoke one pack of cigarettes a day. Her physical examination is normal. Her Pap smear shows HSIL. All the following factors increase her risk for cervical dysplasia EXCEPT:
The most common symptom of endometrial hyperplasia is:
Gold standard for endometrial polyp diagnosis is:

A 62-year-old G2P2, menopausal for 10yrs, complains of occasional right lower quadrant discomfort. US: 15cm complex ovarian mass with cystic and solid components, internal septations, increased Doppler flow, and ascites. Next best step:

A 42-year-old NG presents for routine examination. LMP was 3weeks ago. O/E you detect a large mobile mass in right lower quadrant. Pregnancy test is negative. US: 8cm Rt ovarian cystic mass with solid component and calcifications and teeth. Next step is:
All the following are protective against endometrial cancer EXCEPT:
A patient has a ruptured mucinous cystadenoma. Most likely sequalae is:
A 6-year-old girl has irregular vaginal bleeding. She is taller than her peers and has early breast development. Serum gonadotropin levels are low. Most likely diagnosis:
A healthy 53-year-old woman who has not menstruating for lyear and started HRT, has scanty vaginal bleeding for 2days. BMI is 21, normal BP. Most appropriate next step:
options: Take a Pap smear, including endocervical sampling.
Perform TVS to measure endometrial thickness.

questions.stem: A 39-year-old woman P6 presented with postcoital bleeding for the past three months. Your first investigation should be:
A 73-year-old woman presents with scanty vaginal spotting. Her Pap tests have all been normal and last one was at 65yrs. Next step in evaluating her postmenopausal bleeding is:
Regarding uterine sarcoma, choose the correct statement:
options: It is a common tumor arising in the myometrium.
It arises in more than 5% of benign leiomyoma.
Usually suspected when rapid recurrence occurs after myomectomy.
Treatment of choice is external radiotherapy.

questions.stem: An 16-year-old girl developed fever, abdominal pain, vomiting 4 days after laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy for a 6cm cyst containing hair and teeth. Most probable diagnosis:
What is the most common cystic lesion of the ovary:

A 54-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for routine annual examination. For the past year, she has been taking tamoxifen for the prevention of breast cancer. Examination is within normal. The following is likely to develop with tamoxifen:

A 62-year-old mildly obese woman comes to the physician because of vaginal bleeding. Her LMP was 1lyears ago. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. An endometrial biopsy performed showing G1 endometrial adenocarcinoma. Best next step is:
A 55-year-old postmenopausal female presents with "period-like" vaginal bleeding for 5days that stop spontaneously. Best approach to diagnosis of this patient's problem would be to:
options: Reassure the patient and manage expectantly.
Perform a Pap smear plus endocervical curettage.

questions.stem: A 51-year-old woman is diagnosed with invasive cervical carcinoma by cone biopsy. PV & PR reveal the parametrium to be free, but the upper portion of the vagina is involved with the tumor. IVP and sigmoidoscopy are negative. This patient is classified as stage:
The risk of endometrial cancer is increased in the following condition:
A 45-year-old multipara with regular and average cycles, presented by repeated bleeding following sexual intercourse. Possible causes include which one of the following:
In cases of cervical cancer, radical hysterectomy with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy can potentially be used to treat all the following stages of cervical cancer EXCEPT:

A 60-year-old fit patient presents with 3months history of intermittent vaginal bleeding. she has been menopausal since 55-year-old. She has intermittent lower abdominal pain. No postcoital bleeding, weight loss or anorexia. She is not on HRT. TVS shows ET: 15mm, pipelle biopsy confirms endometrial adenocarcinoma. at TAH+ BSO, the left ovary was noted to contain solid tumor. Most likely diagnosis:
What in the personal history is a protective factor for endometrial cancer:
A 52-year-old woman has recently been diagnosed with severe HSIL on cervical smear. LLETZ shows CIN3 incompletely excised at the endocervical margin. Best next step:
options: Smear and HPV DNA testing in 6months.

questions.stem: A 21-year-old woman presents with an abdominal mass & lower abdominal pain. At laparotomy, the tumor appeared solid, fleshy and pink. Unilateral salphingo-oophorectomy was performed. The histology showed T-cell lymphoid infiltration of the fibrous stroma. Most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old girl presents with an abdominal mass & abdominal pain. A laparotomy and unilateral salphingo-oophorectomy was performed. The histology report shows a meso- dermal core with a central capillary (Schiller-Duval body). This most likely:
Histology report of a patient who had a laparotomy for an abdominal mass that was inoperable, showed a tumor with signet-ring' cells. Most likely origin of 1ry cancer:
A 38-year-old woman presents with an ultrasound scan report showing a unilocular anechoic left ovarian cyst measuring 5.6x 5.2x5 cm. The CA-125 is 25. What is her risk of malignancy index (RMI)?
A 30-year-old woman has had her cervical screening result reported as borderline. What will be your plan of management?
A 35-year-old woman is found to be 15 weeks pregnant when she is diagnosed with stage IB cervical cancer. What will be the most appropriate management?
options: Delay treatment until after fetal maturity.
Delay treatment until after delivery at term.
Immediate chemoradiation after termination of the pregnancy.
Immediate chemoradiation followed by surgery after delivery.
Immediate radical hysterectomy and bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy.

questions.stem: A 40-year-old woman presents with severe vulval pruritus. Vulvoscopy reveals acetowhite areas following application of acetic acid. Vulval biopsy reveals VIN. She can be treated with which of the following?

A 74-year-old woman presents with vulval soreness. Examination reveals a 2 cm mass on the right labia away from the midline. A biopsy of the lesion reveals squamous cell carcinoma with depth of invasion <1 mm. The MRI of the pelvis reveals the same vulva mass with no other abnormality. Best management:
options: Radical vulvectomy with groin lymphadenectomy on the same side.
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral groin lymphadenectomy.
Wide local excision of vulval lesion.
Wide local excision of vulval lesion with groin lymphadenectomy on the same side.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding and vomiting for 2 months following normal VD. Abdominal and pelvic examination reveals a bulky uterus. Most probable diagnosis is:
Which of the following is a predisposing factor for ovarian carcinoma?
The following ovarian tumor has a higher incidence for malignant transformation:
An unmarried 20-year-old female has an accidentally discovered 2 cm hemorrhagic cyst during an abdominal ultrasound. Which of the following is the best treatment for her?
options: Aspiration of the cyst guided by ultrasound.
Cyclic combined oral contraceptive pills for 3 months.

questions.stem: A 6cm nontender, mobile, right adnexal mass is present in a 19-year-old woman. One year ago, while using OCPs, she was hospitalized for left leg deep vein thrombophlebitis. TVS shows a 4cm unilocular smooth ovarian cyst. A serum pregnancy test is negative. Most appropriate next step:

A 66-year-old nulliparous obese, diabetic, hypertensive patient presented with recurrent post- menopausal bleeding. US revealed endometrium thickness of 12 mm. An endometrial biopsy is taken and sent for histopathological assessment. What is the most likely histopathological diagnosis?

While reviewing a cervical biopsy, squamous cell atypia is noted. It extends to a little more than one half the thickness of the epithelium. Beyond that level, maturation is evident. There is no invasion of basement membrane. The correct diagnosis of these findings:
According to FIGO staging of cancer cervix, stage III is assigned when the following occurs:
options: The carcinoma has infiltrated the bladder base.
The carcinoma involves the distal vaginal mucosa.
The carcinoma has extended into the parametrium, but not the pelvic wall.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old woman with PCOS has infertility of 1year duration. Her menses occur at irregular intervals, BBTs are monophasic. An endometrial biopsy shows endometrial hyperplasia with mild cytologic atypia. The most appropriate therapy is:
A 45-year-old P2+0., presented with irregular vaginal bleeding. Endometrial curettage revealed complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. How can you council this case?
options: Endometrial ablation is the preferred option.
Pelvic irradiation is an alternative option.
Medical treatment by progestagens for about 6 months.
Follow up and repeat curettage after 6 months.

questions.stem: A 48-year-old married woman presenting with heavy period for 8months duration. Her periods are getting increasingly heavy. The possible differential diagnosis of this case include all EXCEPT:
The following investigations are recommended EXCEPT:
Surgical treatment of abnormal uterine bleeding include the following options EXCEPT:
A 65-year-old woman is having uterine fibroids. Over 1year, she is noted to have an enlargement of her uterus from 12weeks size to 20weeks size. Which of the following is the best management?
The lymphatic drainage of the cervix is to the following lymph nodes EXCEPT:
Carcinoma in situ of the cervix implies:
options: Extensive glandular involvement of cancer cells.
Full thickness epithelium replacement by undifferentiated cancer cells.
Partial epithelial replacement of stratified basal cells.
Nests of malignant basal cells throughout epithelium

questions.stem: What is the main value of adding progesterone to estrogen in HRT in menopausal women?
A 40-year-old woman is seen for routine examination. Her menses are regular, she has no complaints. Pelvic examination is normal. Her Pap smear shows HSIL. Best next step is:
options: Repeat Pap smear at 3 months interval.
Punch biopsy of anterior cervical lip.

questions.stem: The following is associated with increased risk of endometrial cancer:

A 60-year-old menopausal for 8 years, P1+2, presents with an attack of mild vaginal bleeding. Examination is unremarkable apart from accidently discovered hypertension. US shows a 9mm endometrial thickness. How would you proceed?
The following reflects the etiology of CIN and cervical cancer:
options: HPV is the major causal agent.
There is a strong genetic component to the development of cervical cancer.

questions.stem: Regarding colposcopy:
options: It should be done to all cases with a normal Pap smear.
It is required for staging of cancer cervix cases.
It can detect mitotic activities which correlate with prognosis.
Areas stained brown with Schiller iodine are suspicious of malignancy.

questions.stem: Contact bleeding may be a presentation of all of the following EXCEPT:
All the following are risk factors for endometrial carcinoma EXCEPT:
According to FIGO staging, endometrial cancer with downward spread to cervix is:
According to FIGO, stage III cervical cancer is characterized by:
options: Lateral spread to compress the ureter.
Mucosal spread to the urinary bladder.

questions.stem: Staging of endometrial cancer entails:
options: Clinical staging: physical examination, pyelogram, chest X-Ray and anoscopy.
Clinical staging: physical examination, pyelogram, chest X-Ray and CT scan.
Surgical staging: TAH+ BSO, pelvic washings, pelvic & para-aortic lymphadenectomy.
Surgical staging: TAH+ BSO, pelvic nodes, pelvic washing and omentectomy.

questions.stem: The following is a non-neoplastic cyst of the ovary:

The following predispose to ovarian cancer EXCEPT:
A 45-year-old woman complains of irregular vaginal bleeding of 10 months duration. TVS revealed a 4 cm interstitial myoma and endometrial thickness of 15 mm. Best management:
A 58-year-old woman is having surgery for an ovarian mass. At surgery there are external papillae. The pathologist on frozen notes psammoma bodies. Most likely etiology of her mass is:
The most commonly diagnosed gynecological malignancy in developed countries is:

A 37-year-old G2P2 reports irregular menses, and recent increase in facial and body hair. O/E, patient had acne, facial hair, 10cm left adnexal mass. PV confirms 10cm mass arising from the left ovary. the following serum concentration is most likely elevated:
All the following are protective against endometrial cancer, EXCEPT:
The gold standard treatment for stage I endometrial carcinoma is:
options: Follow up by fractional curettage annually.

questions.stem: Comparing various gynecologic malignancies regarding prognosis, the following is the worst:
Why this malignancy, chosen in the previous question, has the worst prognosis:
options: Patient is usually old and unfit for surgery.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old multipara menopausal for 7 years presented by an attack of mild vaginal bleeding. Causes include all the following EXCEPT:
Which of the following ovarian masses has a higher incidence for torsion?

A 25-year-old patient is being followed for a 5cm right ovarian cystic mass. She comes to the ER with sudden severe right sided lower abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. O/E there was a severely tender 10cm right pelvic mass. TLC: 12.500. The patient undergoes laparoscopy and a black mass is seen replacing the entire ovary. The most appropriate management of the patient is:
A 21-year-old healthy female using OCP is found to have a 2mm pigmented flat lesion with irregular margins is seen on the left labia. Most appropriate next step:
HPV that is most often associated with CIN III is:

A 57-year-old morbidly obese diabetic, hypertensive patient presents with postmenopausal bleeding. An office endometrial biopsy shows complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, and US shows multiple uterine fibroids. Best management is:

A 57-year-old G3P3 presents with 6months history of pelvic discomfort, increased abdominal girth and early satiety. O/E: large abdominopelvic mass. US and CT show bilateral ovarian masses, ascites, and studding of the peritoneum. You predict it is most likely a malignant ovarian. She asks about the 1ry method of ttt for her condition:
Regarding cancer cervix, choose the correct statement:
options: 1ry prevention by HPV vaccine is not effective.
Staging of definite cases should be surgical.
Spread is mainly through direct and lymphatic spread.
Radiotherapy is preferred in young patients to preserve ovaries.

questions.stem: Functioning ovarian tumors include one of the following:
Predisposing factors for ovarian malignancy include:
options: Prolonged use of oral contraceptive pills.

questions.stem: Regarding cancer cervix, choose the correct statement:
options: 1ry prevention by H.P.V vaccine is effective.
FIGO staging of definite cases is a surgical one.
Spread is mainly through blood stream.
Radiotherapy is preferred in young patients to preserve ovaries.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old P2+0, with tubal ligation, presents by irregular vaginal bleeding. Endometrial curettage shows complex hyperplasia with atypia. How can you council her?
options: Endometrial ablation is the preferred option.
Pelvic irradiation is an alternative option.
Medical treatment by progestogens for about 6 months.
Follow up and repeat curettage after 6 months.

questions.stem: An obese healthy 63-year-old woman presents with mild vaginal bleeding. No use of HRT. Pap smear is negative. The next step is:
options: Perform colposcopic evaluation of the cervix.
Obtain serum FSH, LH, E2, PRL.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old G1P1, menopausal for 10 years, presents with repeated attacks of moderate vaginal bleeding. She is hypertensive with poor control. Speculum examination is free and US reveals AVF bulky uterus with a 20 mm endometrial thickness. Your suggested cause for this bleeding:
A 45-year-old multipara with regular and average cycles, presented by repeated bleeding following sexual intercourse. Possible causes include:
An increased incidence of endometrial hyperplasia has been described in patients with:
A 46-year-old multiparous patient presents with contact bleeding. Speculum examination reveals suspicious cervix. The cervical biopsy taken will most likely be:

A 50-year-old woman complains of irregular vaginal bleeding of 7 months duration. Pelvic examination demonstrates a normal AVF uterus, normal appearing cervix and no adnexal masses. Pregnancy test is negative. Definitive diagnosis of this patient is by which of the followings?
If this patient is proved to have complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, your preferred further management will be:
A 47-year-old married woman presents with heavy period for 8 months duration. Her periods are getting increasingly heavy. All the following are possible differential diagnoses EXCEPT:
All the following investigations are recommended EXCEPT:
Ovarian cancer is more likely to occur in all the following EXCEPT:
options: Patient with history of prolonged use of oral contraceptive pills.
Women with a family history of ovarian cancer.

questions.stem: The commonest site for metastasis from ovarian cancer is:

A 26-year-old G2P1 presents with increasing hair growth on her face, chest and abdomen. But hair on her head is receding in the temporal regions. She also has had problems with acne. O/E, the patient has significant amounts of coarse dark hair on face, chest and abdomen with enlarged clitoris. She has a 7cm left adnexal mass.
A 56-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. Uterus is slightly enlarged and she has a 6cm Rt adnexal mass. Endometrial biopsy shows endometrial adenocarcinoma.
A 67-year-old woman is found to have bilateral adnexal masses while undergoing evaluation of her recently diagnosed colon cancer.

A 17-year-old woman is referred for the evaluation of primary amenorrhea. O/E: the patient has evidence of virilization. she also has a pelvic mass. during the workup of the patient, she is found to have sex chromosome mosaicism (45XO/46XY).
A 29-year-old woman is undergoing diagnostic laparoscopy for a 9cm right ovarian mass. The final pathology report shows evidence of glial tissue and immature cerebellar and cortical tissue.
A 51-year-old menopausal woman is undergoing exploratory laparotomy for bilateral adnexal masses. A frozen section on the excised ovaries and shows significant numbers of signet cells.
Tumor Marker: Struma ovarii.
Tumor Marker: Sertoli- Leydig cell tumor.
Tumor Marker: Granulosa cell tumor.
Tumor Marker: Dysgerminoma.
Tumor Marker: Mucinous cystadenoma.
Tumor Marker: Yolk sac tumor.
Tumor Marker: Breast cancer.
Tumor Marker: Choriocarcinoma.
Tumor Marker: Functioning brenner tumor.
Tumor Marker: Endodermal sinus tumor.
Tumor Marker: Thecoma.
Infection with HPV is a major risk.
CA 125 is the main marker.
Has the best prognosis due to early clinical diagnosis and effective response to chemotherapy.
Lower incidence in women who breast fed their babies and used COCPs for long periods.
Well identified familial predisposition.
CA 125 is commonly used in initial diagnosis and follow up after ttt.
LDH is commonly used in initial diagnosis and follow up.
Radiotherapy as a sole ttt gives the same curative results as surgery.
Prolonged unopposed estrogen is the main predisposing factor.
Uterine submucous fibroid.
Pelvic endometriosis.
Cervical carcinoma.
Ovulatory cycle.
Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor.
Ashermann Syndrome.
Endometrial carcinoma.
Subserous myoma.
Dermoid cyst.
Benign ovarian tumor with highest incidence to turn malignant is dermoid cyst.
Theca lutein cysts present in association to choriocarcinoma, need immediate laparoscopic intervention.
Metastatic ovarian tumors may have a Iry in the breast or stomach.
Pregnancy is a predisposing factor for ovarian cyst torsion.
The commonest cause of postmenopausal bleeding is atrophic vaginitis/ endometritis.
In ovarian neoplasm, the presence of ascites on ultrasound is a predictor for malignancy.
Breast cancer is the commonest cancer of the female genital organs.
Dermoid cyst is the commonest ovarian tumor in the childbearing age.
Most preventable female genital tract cancer is cervical cancer.
Female genital tract cancer with the best prognosis is endometrial cancer.
If a pap cervical smear shows mild dysplasia, the next step in management would include treatment of inflammation then repeating the smear.
HPV is a predisposing factor for vulval cancer.
Butterfly incision for vulval cancer has a low morbidity and mortality results.
HSV2 is a predisposing factor for cervical cancer.
